abstract.text: A factory class for creating layout constraint objects using a fluent API.

inlineContent.text: Use these constraints to programatically define your layout using Auto Layout. Instead of creating
object you wish to constrain, and select one of that object’s anchor properties. These properties correspond to the main
values used in Auto Layout, and provide an appropriate
subclass for creating constraints to that attribute. Use the anchor’s methods to construct your constraint.

inlineContent.text: As you can see from these examples, the
class provides several advantages over using the
The code is cleaner, more concise, and easier to read.
subclasses provide additional type checking, preventing you from creating invalid constraints.
class provides additional type checking, it is still possible to create invalid constraints. For example, the compiler allows you to constrain one view’s
instances. However, Auto Layout does not allow constraints that mix leading and trailing attributes with left or right attributes. As a result, this constraint crashes at runtime.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A factory class for creating layout constraint objects using a fluent API.
Returns a constraint that defines one item’s attribute as equal to another.
Returns a constraint that defines one item’s attribute as equal to another item’s attribute plus a constant offset.
Returns a constraint that defines one item’s attribute as greater than or equal to another.
Returns a constraint that defines one item’s attribute as greater than or equal to another item’s attribute plus a constant offset.
Returns a constraint that defines one item’s attribute as less than or equal to another.
Returns a constraint that defines one item’s attribute as less than or equal to another item’s attribute plus a constant offset.
The constraints that impact the layout of the anchor.
A Boolean value indicating whether the constraints impacting the anchor specify its location ambiguously.
The layout item used to calculate the anchor’s position.
The name assigned to the anchor for debugging purposes.
The relationship between two user interface objects that must be satisfied by the constraint-based layout system.
The part of the object’s visual representation that should be used to get the value for the constraint.
A factory class for creating size-based layout constraint objects using a fluent API.
A rectangular area that can interact with Auto Layout.
A factory class for creating horizontal layout constraint objects using a fluent API.
A factory class for creating vertical layout constraint objects using a fluent API.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
A layout anchor representing the bottom edge of the view’s frame.
A layout anchor representing the leading edge of the view’s frame.
A layout anchor representing the left edge of the view’s frame.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
